Body:
I'm working on a personal project where I want a PC to send a message to a Raspberry Pi. Since they are not going to be in the same network and I don't want to work with port forwarding, I tried using Weaved; however, I can't get the Raspberry Pi to receive any of the messages I'm sending from the PC.

The code for the Pi looks like this:

   # Message Receiver	import os	from socket import *	host = "	port = 13000	buf = 1024	addr = (host, port)	UDPSock = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_DGRAM)	UDPSock.bind(addr)	print Waiting to receive messages..."	while True:	    (data
column9:
addr) = UDPSock.recvfrom(buf) print "Received message: " + data if data == "exit": break UDPSock.close()

For the PC the code looks like this:

# Message Sender	import os	from socket import *	host = "127.0.0.1" # set to IP address of target computer	port = 13000	addr = (host
column11: SOCK_DGRAM)	while True:	    data = raw_input("Enter message to send or type 'exit': ")	    UDPSock.sendto(data
column12:
addr) if data == "exit": break UDPSock.close() os._exit(0)

I've configuered the Weaved service to custom. I really need help
column13:
but I'm not sure that what I am doing is right.

The logic is correct in some way
column14:
because this works if the PC is in the same network as the Pi.

Thanks for the help!

"

Body: I was able to fix the problem. It was something else entirely. Instead of using TCP, I was actually using UDP. @Jackie I didn't even touch the manifest file, don't think it was needed. Thank you for the help anyway.
Just wondering, have you enabled the Internet client/Private network client capability in your project manifest file?
